questions.text: Which among the following is an outlet forceps?

A 31-year-old female presented with a history of vaginal delivery 2 days ago and complained of pain and sensory loss in the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. Which of the following nerves is involved?
questions.correct_answer: D. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.explanation:
NST (Nonstress Test)

Fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements

AFI (Amniotic Fluid Index)

Measurement of amniotic fluid volume

Non-reactive NST or AFI <5

Non-reassuring (abnormal result)

Reactive NST and AFI ≥ 5

Reassuring (normal result)

Parameter

Normal Criteria

Breathing Movements

>1 episode lasting >30 seconds

Amniotic Fluid Volume

≥1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes

Fetal Tone

≥1 episode of active limb or trunk extension with return of flexion (e.g., opening and closing of the hand)

Gross Body Movements

>3 discrete body/limb movements

Non-stress Test (NST)

Reactive pattern (Two accelerations of 15 seconds duration, 15 bpm, in 20 minutes)

BPP Score

Interpretation

Management

10

Normal, non-asphyxiated fetus

No action required; Routine monitoring

8

Normal, non-asphyxiated fetus

Repeat test weekly or biweekly for high-risk pregnancies (e.g., diabetic, post-term)

6

Possible fetal asphyxia

Repeat testing; If score ≤6, consider delivery

4

Probable fetal asphyxia

Repeat test same day or deliver if AFV is abnormal or >36 weeks

0-2

Almost certain fetal asphyxia

Immediate delivery

questions.text: In the radiological evaluation of a pregnant woman, it is observed that the pelvic inlet appears oval-shaped and has the largest diameter in the anteroposterior direction. According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification, the pelvis is likely to be?
What is the adverse effect linked to intravenous bolus administration of oxytocin?
questions.explanation:
Different Side Effects Of Oxytocin And Their Causes

Side Effects

Causes

Uterine Hyperstimulation
  • High dosage or rapid increase in Oxytocin infusion rate
  • Prolonged administration of Oxytocin

Fetal Distress

Uterine hyperstimulation leading to decreased blood flow and oxygen supply to the fetus

Water Intoxication

Prolonged high-dose administration of Oxytocin

Nausea and Vomiting

Direct stimulation of the vomiting center in the brain by Oxytocin

Headache

Vasodilation and changes in cerebral blood flow caused by Oxytocin

Hypotension

Oxytocin-induced vasodilation and decreased systemic vascular resistance

Postpartum Hemorrhage

Rarely, high doses of Oxytocin may contribute to uterine atony or excessive uterine contractions

Allergic Reactions

Hypersensitivity or allergic response to Oxytocin or other components of the medication

Cardiac Arrhythmias

Direct effects of Oxytocin on cardiac electrical activity

Maternal Fluid Overload

Oxytocin-induced antidiuretic effect leading to fluid retention

Uterine Rupture (Rare)

Excessive uterine contractions or hyperstimulation of the uterus

Use

Recommended Dose

Adverse Effects

Induction of Labor

Initial: 0.5-1 milliunits/min IV infusion, gradually increasing by 1-2 milliunits/min every 15-60 min until desired contractions occur
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Fetal distress
  • Water intoxication (rare, with prolonged high-dose administration)

Augmentation of Labor

Initial: 0.5-1 milliunits/min IV infusion, gradually increasing by 1-2 milliunits/min every 15-60 min as needed
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Fetal distress

Prevention of Postpartum Hemorrhage

IV infusion: 10-40 units in 1000 mL of compatible IV solution, usually at a rate of 20-40 milliunits/min
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Postpartum hemorrhage (rare, when given in excessive doses)

Management of Postpartum Hemorrhage

IV infusion: 10 units in 1000 mL of compatible IV solution, usually at a rate of 20-40 milliunits/min
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Postpartum hemorrhage (rare, when given in excessive doses)

Uterine Atony

IV infusion: 10-20 units in 1000 mL of compatible IV solution, usually at a rate of 20-40 milliunits/min
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Postpartum hemorrhage (rare, when given in excessive doses)

Facilitation of Placental Delivery

IV infusion: 10 units in 1000 mL of compatible IV solution, usually at a rate of 20-40 milliunits/min
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Postpartum hemorrhage (rare, when given in excessive doses)

Stimulation of Breast Milk Ejection

Intranasal spray: Single spray (40 IU) into one nostril approximately 5-10 min before breastfeeding or pumping
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Headache
  • Hypotension (rare)

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours, and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management?
questions.explanation:

3

Closed

1-2

3-4

≥5

Length (Effacement)

>4 or 0-30%

3-4 or 40-50%

1-2 or 50-70%

0 ≥80%

Consistency

Firm

Medium

Soft

--

Position

Posterior

Midline

Anterior

--

Head Station

-3

-2

-1,0

+1,+2

Good score: ≥9

Unfavorable score: ≤4

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) for the management of the second stage of labor?

options.label: B
options.text: Manual perineal support and warm compresses

options.label: C
options.text: Maintain head in deflexion and deliver

questions.correct_answer: B. Manual perineal support and warm compresses

questions.text: Which of the following is a part of AMTSL?
questions.explanation:
Advantages of AMTSL
  • Minimised Blood Loss
  • Shortened Duration

Disadvantages
  • Slightly increased incidence of retained placenta
  • Risk of asphyxia in the second twin if administered prematurely.

Indications

High-risk factors include anaemia, hydroamnios, twins, grand multiparae, and a previous history of postpartum haemorrhage (PPH).

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not cut in a mediolateral episiotomy?

options.label: D
options.text: Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves

questions.explanation:
Type

Advantages

Disadvantages

Mediolateral

(most prevalent)
  • Reduced risk of severe perineal tears.
  • May facilitate easier delivery.
  • Less risk of injury to the anal sphincter compared to the midline.
  • Higher risk of postpartum pain and discomfort.
  • Potential for increased blood loss compared to other types.

Median
  • Simplicity in execution.
  • Less postoperative pain compared to mediolateral.
  • Higher risk of severe perineal tears, including anal sphincter injury.
  • Potential for increased healing time and complications due to midline orientation.

questions.text: Identify the grip shown in the image below.
Modified Robson's classification class 1 includes which of the following:

options.label: C
options.text: Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour

options.label: D
options.text: Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.correct_answer: B. Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour
questions.explanation:
Group

Description

1

Nulliparous, single cephalic ≥37 weeks, in spontaneous labor

2

Nulliparous, single cephalic, ≥37 weeks induced or C-section (CS) before labor

3

Multiparous (excluding previous CS), single cephalic, ≥37 weeks, in spontaneous labor

4

Multiparous (excluding previous CS), single cephalic, ≥37 weeks, induced or CS before labor

5

Previous CS, single cephalic, ≥37 weeks

6

All nulliparous breeches

7

All multiparous breeches (including previous CS)

8

All multiple pregnancies (including previous CS)

9

All abnormal lies (including previous CS)

10

All single cephalic, ≥37 weeks (including previous CS)

questions.text: Identify the fetal position in the image below.
What is the obstetric grip being depicted in the image?
questions.explanation:
Maneuver

Position

Technique

Purpose

Fundal Grip

(First Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Palpate the fundal area with both hands

To determine which fetal pole is in the fundus:

  • Broad, soft, irregular mass: Breech
  • Smooth, hard, globular mass: Head
  • Transverse lie: Neither pole palpable

Lateral or Umbilical Grip

(Second Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place hands flat on either side of the umbilicus, palpate one side at a time

To identify the position of the fetal back, limbs, and anterior shoulder:

  • Back: Smooth, curved, resistant
  • Limb side: Comparatively empty with small, knob-like parts
  • Anterior shoulder: Prominent in the lower part of the uterus above the head

Pawlik’s Grip

(Third Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place thumb and four fingers over the lower pole of the uterus, ulnar border on the upper symphysis pubis

To grasp the presenting part if not engaged and test its mobility:

Transverse lie: Pawlik’s grip is empty

Pelvic Grip

(Fourth Leopold)

Facing the patient’s feet

Place four fingers of both hands on either side of the midline in the lower pole of the uterus, pressing downward and backward
  • To identify the part in the lower pole, its attitude, and engagement:

Head Characteristics:

  1. Precise presenting area
  2. Attitude (position of sinciput and occiput)
  3. Engagement (noted by the presence/absence of sinciput and occiput, convergence/divergence of finger tips)

questions.text: In the anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet, the true conjugate is?

options.label: A
options.text: The distance from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis

options.label: B
options.text: The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis

options.label: C
options.text: The distance from the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory

options.label: D
options.text: The distance from the posterior margin of the sacral promontory to the symphysis pubis

questions.correct_answer: A. The distance from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis
questions.explanation:
True Conjugate (Conjugata Vera)

The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the superior margin of the pubic symphysis.

Determines pelvic inlet adequacy for vaginal delivery; <9.5 cm suggests possible cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD).

Diagonal Conjugate

(Option C)

The distance between the sacral promontory and the lower margin of the pubic symphysis, measured via the vaginal exam.

Estimates true conjugate; <12 cm may indicate a narrow pelvic inlet.

Obstetric Conjugate

(Option B)

The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis.

Assesses pelvic cavity adequacy for fetal head passage; inadequate may lead to obstructed labor.

questions.text: A primigravida presents with labor pain, and on per vaginal examination, her cervix is 7 cm dilated and fully effaced. What stage of labor is she in?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Definition

Features

Contractions

First Stage

Onset of labor to full cervical dilatation (10 cm).

  • Latent Phase: Early cervical changes with slower progress.
  • Active Phase: Faster cervical dilatation (≥5 cm) with regular contractions.
  • Cervical dilatation and effacement occur.
  • Intermittent painful uterine contractions.
  • "Show" (blood-stained mucus) is common.
  • Active labor starts at cervical dilatation ≥5 cm with regular contractions.

Latent Phase: Irregular and mild.

Active Phase: Regular; 3–5 min apart, lasting ~45 seconds.

Second Stage

From complete cervical dilatation (10 cm) to fetal delivery.
  • Begins after complete cervical dilation.
  • Ends with the delivery of the baby.

Strong and frequent; 2–3 minutes apart.

Third Stage

From fetal delivery to placental expulsion.
  • Placental separation and expulsion occur.
  • Average duration: 5–15 minutes.

Mild uterine contractions to aid placental expulsion.

Fourth Stage

Observation for at least 1 hour after placental expulsion.
  • Monitoring for postpartum hemorrhage and uterine contraction.

Uterine contractions continue, aiding hemostasis.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent techniques for cervical ripening belongs to the category of hygroscopic dilators?

options.label: C
options.text: Foley catheter at internal of cervix
